categories.name: Television
categories.description: Television advertising is a form of advertising where commercials are aired on television networks or stations.

categories.name: Radio
categories.description: Radio advertising is a form of advertising where commercials are aired on radio stations.

categories.name: Periodicals
categories.description: Periodicals are publications released at regular intervals, such as newspapers, magazines, and journals. Advertising in periodicals refers to ads placed in these publications.

categories.name: Out of Home
categories.description: Out-of-home advertising is advertising that reaches the consumers while they are outside their homes, such as billboards or transit ads.

categories.name: Yellow Pages
categories.description: Yellow Pages advertising refers to ads placed in the Yellow Pages, a telephone directory of businesses.

categories.name: Direct Mail
categories.description: Direct mail is a form of advertising where marketers send printed marketing materials to the homes of consumers.

categories.name: Internet
categories.description: Internet advertising is a form of advertising that is delivered through websites, email, and social media.

categories.name: Miscellaneous
categories.description: Advertising that does not fit into any of the other categories, or the category is unknown.

ads.name: A skin you love to touch
ads.short_name: A skin you love to touch
ads.slogan: A skin you love to touch
ads.description: In 1911, Woodbury Soap Company became the first company to use sex appeal to sell a product. Their ad slogan, created by the J. Walter Thompson Agency, claimed that women who used the soap would have A Skin You Love To Touch. The slogan became so popular that Woodbury used it until the 1940s.

ads.name: So long till Monday!
ads.description: Indian Motorcycles, manufactured by the Hendee Manufacturing Company (later renamed the Indian Motorcycle Manufacturing Company) of Springfield, Massachusetts, were the first motorcycles to be manufactured in America. The Company's co-owners, George Hendee and Carl Oscar Hedstrom, focused on technological innovations that would increase the speed and horsepower of their motorcycles, and in 1916 they released a model with a Powerplus engine. Indian Motorcycles from this era were used by the United States military during World War I, as well as by police departments across the nation.

ads.name: Lemon
ads.slogan: We pluck the lemons, you get the plums

ads.name: I'd like to buy the world a Coke
Where's the beef?

ads.name: Just Do It
ads.description: The Just Do It campaign was launched by Nike in 1988 to promote the company's line of athletic shoes and apparel. The campaign was created by the advertising agency Wieden+Kennedy, and it was designed to inspire people to push themselves to achieve their goals. The campaign featured a series of television commercials that showed athletes overcoming obstacles and achieving success, and it was accompanied by the slogan Just Do It. The campaign was a huge success, and it helped to establish Nike as one of the leading brands in the sports industry.

ads.name: Think different
ads.description: The Think Different campaign was launched by Apple in 1997 to promote the company's Macintosh computer. The campaign featured black-and-white photographs of famous people, including Albert Einstein, John Lennon, and Mahatma Gandhi, along with the slogan Think Different. The campaign was created by the advertising agency TBWA\Chiat\Day, and it was designed to emphasize Apple's commitment to innovation and creativity.

ads.name: Campaign for Real Beauty
ads.slogan: Real beauty comes in all shapes and sizes
ads.description: The Campaign for Real Beauty was launched by Dove in 2004 to promote the company's line of beauty products.
